node.title: The toilet on the Crew Dragon capsule is out of service. The crew will have to use diapers.
node.alt: The Crew Dragon toilet, upper right, which is currently out of service.
node.description: The malfunctioning toilet was first detected in another SpaceX capsule last month.
node.content: ["Last week, the SpaceX Crew-2 capsule was all clear to make its trek back home, but one thing stood in the way: its toilet. While the vehicle has been cleared to return to Earth, the toilet is going to remain offline for the duration of the trip.", "If the astronauts need to go, they\u2019re going to have to hold it, or use astronaut-grade diapers built into their flight suits as a contingency.", "\u201cOf course that\u2019s suboptimal, but we are prepared to manage that in the time that we\u2019re onboard Dragon on the way home,\u201d K. Megan McArthur, the Crew-2 mission pilot, said during a news conference on Friday.", "The acorn-shaped capsule is somewhat larger than a minivan on Earth; it doesn\u2019t have a proper bathroom. Instead it has a toilet device with a tube and fans built into one of the spacecraft\u2019s compartments that create suction to ensure waste goes in the right direction in the weightlessness of space.", "In September, SpaceX detected a leaky toilet on another one of its capsules during the flight of Inspiration4, a three-day orbital journey of private astronauts that didn\u2019t dock at the space station, according to Bill Gerstenmaier, a company vice president who discussed the toilet problems during a news conference in October.", "A tube from the capsule\u2019s toilet that funnels waste into an internal tank broke loose and leaked fluids into a fan, which sent urine throughout an area beneath the capsule\u2019s interior floor, Mr. Gerstenmaier said.", "When SpaceX engineers discovered the flaw, they instructed astronauts on the space station to inspect their Crew-2 capsule. They found similar traces of urine beneath the interior floor, which worried officials that it could corrode some of the capsule\u2019s aluminum parts and pose a safety risk for the return flight.", "SpaceX engineers conducted experiments on the ground to test whether urine, which is mixed with an ammonia-removing compound called oxone, could corrode the aluminum. The parts sat in a chamber that mimicked the humidity conditions aboard the space station for \u201can extended period of time,\u201d Mr. Gerstenmaier said.", "From the experiment and inspections of the Inspiration4 capsule, SpaceX found that the urine-oxone mixture had little effect on the aluminum parts because of heavy coats of paint on Crew Dragon that are \u201ca great blocking agent to the liquid,\u201d Sarah Walker, SpaceX\u2019s mission management director for Crew Dragon, told reporters during a news conference.", "\u201cWe learned that the liquid evaporates within just a couple days,\u201d Ms. Walker added, \u201cand that really limits the impact that we observed when we were doing all of our post-flight inspections.\u201d", "NASA officials approved the results of the experiments and deemed Crew-2 safe to return to Earth. SpaceX proposed a permanent fix to future Crew Dragon capsules that should ensure the urine tube would not come undone.", "But the toilet leak on the Crew-2 capsule remains, meaning that astronauts heeding the call of nature in orbit must use the \u201cundergarments\u201d in their flight suits, Steve Stich, NASA\u2019s Commercial Crew program manager, told reporters on Oct. 31.", "\u201cOur intent is to not use the system at all for the return leg home, because of what we\u2019ve seen with the fluid,\u201d Mr. Stich said. \u201cAny time the crew is suited, they use an undergarment in that suit, and it\u2019s a short mission coming home so it\u2019s pretty typical to have an undergarment on and they can use that on the way home.\u201d", "\u201cSpaceflight is full of lots of little challenges,\u201d Dr. McArthur said. \u201cThis is just one more that we\u2019ll encounter and take care of on our mission.\u201d"]
